page.title: 02ARMED FORCES DARTMOOR
page.content: On Halsanger Common near Rippon Tor the butt of a firing range stands out against the sky. The rifle range was built in 1941 to train soldiers fighting in World War Two. The range has not been used by the army for the past ten years. The National Park Committee objected to its use on the grounds that it was dangerous for the public walking on the moors. Some would like the butt destroyed but the landowner wants it to remain as a piece of wartime archaeology. The butt is made of a brick wall 213 ft. long with 17 brick buttresses facing North and two side walls 54 ft. long with 6 buttresses infilled with earth and sand to form a sloping bank facing South. Distance to first target bank 89 ft. Distance between mounds 250 ft. Length of mounds about 150 ft.
